primaryKeyword: UK Overtime Calculator, Overtime Pay UK
intro: Calculate your overtime pay in the UK with our comprehensive tax calculator. Understanding how overtime is taxed is crucial for maximizing your take-home earnings from extra hours worked. UK law typically requires overtime to be paid at time-and-a-half (1.5x) or double time (2x) your normal hourly rate, but these payments are taxed at your marginal PAYE rate, potentially pushing you into higher tax brackets. This calculator uses official 2026 HMRC rates to show you exactly how much tax you'll pay on overtime earnings, including PAYE income tax, National Insurance contributions (NIC), and pension deductions. Whether you work occasional overtime or regularly put in extra hours, this tool helps you understand the true value of your overtime work.
howThisCalculatorWorks: This UK overtime pay calculator determines your take-home overtime earnings by first calculating the gross overtime pay (base salary ÷ 52 weeks ÷ contracted hours × overtime hours × overtime multiplier), then applying UK tax rates. Overtime is taxed at your marginal rate - if your regular salary puts you in the 20% bracket but overtime pushes you into the 40% bracket, the overtime is taxed at 40%. National Insurance is calculated on total earnings. The calculator shows both the overtime pay breakdown and your total salary including overtime, so you can see the overall tax impact. UK employment law generally requires overtime rates of 1.5x for weekdays and 2x for weekends/holidays, though individual contracts may vary.

overtimeRules.title: UK Overtime Pay Rules
rules: **Legal Requirement:** Most UK employment contracts require overtime pay at premium rates
**Standard Rates:** Time-and-a-half (1.5x) for normal overtime, double time (2x) for weekends/holidays
**Contract Variations:** Some contracts specify different rates or overtime banking arrangements
**Tax Treatment:** Overtime is taxed at marginal rates, potentially in higher tax brackets
**NIC Impact:** Overtime increases total earnings, affecting National Insurance
**Working Time Regulations:** Maximum 48 hours per week averaged over 17 weeks (can be opted out)

faqs.question: How is overtime taxed in the UK?
faqs.answer: Overtime pay is taxed at your marginal PAYE rate. If your regular salary puts you in the 20% bracket but overtime pushes you into the 40% bracket, the overtime is taxed at 40%. National Insurance is calculated on your total earnings.

faqs.question: What's the standard overtime rate in the UK?
faqs.answer: UK law generally requires time-and-a-half (1.5x your normal rate) for overtime worked on weekdays, and double time (2x) for overtime worked on weekends or bank holidays.

faqs.question: Does overtime affect my tax bracket?
faqs.answer: Yes, overtime increases your total annual earnings, potentially pushing you into higher PAYE tax brackets and NIC bands. The overtime itself is taxed at your new marginal rate.

faqs.question: Can I bank overtime instead of getting paid immediately?
faqs.answer: Some UK employers offer overtime banking schemes where you can accumulate overtime hours for future time off. Check your employment contract for specific arrangements.

faqs.question: How do I calculate my overtime rate?
faqs.answer: Divide your annual salary by 52 weeks, then divide by your contracted weekly hours. Multiply by the overtime multiplier (usually 1.5 or 2.0) for your overtime rate.

Whether you're working occasional extra hours or regularly putting in overtime, knowing the true value of your time helps you make informed decisions about work-life balance and compensation. Remember that overtime rates and taxation can vary based on your employment contract and individual circumstances. For personalized advice, consult your employment contract or HMRC.
